books.title: Your Very Own Pet Monster
books.author: Meg Price
books.description: You have a pet monster! Tell me about your pet monster. With this interactive children's book, you get to choose your very own pet monster.  What does it look like? Where does it sleep? What does it do for fun? There are 16 different monsters to discover.

texts.text: You have a pet monster, a wonderful friendly pet monster. Even though it's your pet, it doesn't live in your house. It lives outside.
You love doing fun things when you're spending time with your pet monster. But all monsters are different.
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it have wings or does it have big sharp claws?
Your pet monster has wings! It can fly high above buildings and trees. It can do swooping loops and looping swoops high in the air.
Watching your pet monster fly around is a lot of fun. But where does it sleep?
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it sleep on the branch of a tree in a beautiful forest or does it sleep on top of a building in a big noisy city?
Your pet monster has big sharp claws! Some people might think your pet monster is scary, but you know that it is a nice monster, happy and kind.
Its claws are very useful for all sorts of things like making a place for it to sleep. But where does your pet monster sleep?
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it sleep in a tunnel under the ground with worms or does it live inside a cave in a grassy hill?
Your pet monster lives very high off the ground at the tippy top of the beautiful trees. It eats bugs that fly in the air and bugs that crawl on tree branches.
It snatches them up with its little fingers. When your pet monster isn't sleeping on its tree branch, what does it do for fun?
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it like to play with tennis balls, or does it like swinging on tree branches?
Your pet monster sleeps on the roof of a building. Sometimes it's naughty because it bites off pieces of plastic and metal from rain gutters and aerials.
Whenever someone's television goes a bit funny, it's probably because your pet monster has taken a bite out of the aerial on their roof!
When your pet monster isn't eating things, what does it do for fun? Tell me about your pet monster.
Does it like going to the playground and swinging on the swings or does it like being inside painting pictures?
Your pet monster lives under the ground. It uses its big sharp claws to dig tunnels in the dirt to sleep in.
But your pet monster doesn't sleep very much, it has lots of energy and loves to play. Your pet monster especially likes to play when you're around.
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it like having running races, especially on a red running track, or does it like building castles out of mud and rocks?
Your pet monster lives inside a cave. It used its big sharp claws to dig out a big comfy cave in the side of a grassy hill.
Digging the cave made a bit of mess with rocks and stones everywhere. But that's okay because your pet monster likes to eat rocks and it gobbled up all the mess!
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it like to make statues and masks out of rock and wood or does it like to spend most of its time sleeping?
Your pet monster loves to play with tennis balls. Your pet monster is tiny, even smaller than the ball.
When you throw or hit a tennis ball, your pet monster likes to hang onto the brightly coloured fuzz on the ball and ride it like a horse! It's your pet monster's favourite game.
But what does your tiny pet monster look like? Tell me about your pet monster. Does it have feathers or is it fluffy?
Your pet monster loves to swing in the trees. It is a fantastic acrobat. If monsters could join the circus, your pet monster would be the star of the show!

It hangs from branches with one hand, one foot, and even one wing! It swings and twirls and balances. The best part is, you never have to worry about your pet monster accidentally falling because it can fly!
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it have big googly eyes or no eyes at all?
Your pet monster loves visiting playgrounds and swinging on the swings. But whenever it goes on the slide, it doesn't need to climb the ladder to get to the top because it can fly.

Sometimes your pet monster is naughty and doesn't wait for its turn – while you're climbing the ladder to the top of the slide for your turn, your cheeky pet monster flies right over your head and pushes in front!
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it make grunting and growling noises or does it like whistling a musical tune?
Your pet monster is always very calm. Its favourite thing to do is paint beautiful pictures for you.
The problem is, because your pet monster is very messy, paint gets just about everywhere! Cleaning up after your pet monster has finished painting can be a very tricky job.
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it make terrible stinky farts or does it have long soft hair perfect for brushing?
Your pet monster loves having running races, especially on a bright red running track with hurdles to jump over.
Unfortunately, your pet monster is a sore loser and sulks whenever you come in first. But it's even worse when it wins because it dances and cheers every time it comes in first! What a silly monster.
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it sometimes get big splinters in its feet or does it sometimes fall over when it's running?
Your pet monster loves getting dirty. It loves being dirty so much that it likes to build castles out of mud and rocks. Building mud castles is just like building sand castles.
Your pet monster likes to use a bucket and spade, but sometimes it just uses its hands. Building mud castles is a very fun way to spend an afternoon together.
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it like taking photos with a camera or does it like to slide down big muddy hills?
Your pet monster likes to make statues and masks out of rocks and logs of wood. It uses its big sharp claws to scratch out the shapes.
Your pet monster likes to make statues and masks of people, animals and even other monsters!
Your pet monster also has other toys that it likes to play with sometimes when you're visiting.
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it like to use its masks and other toys to put on a show or does it like to play with a toy that squirts out water?
Your pet monster is as big as a beach ball but much, much heavier! It's always cold and spends most of its day sleeping, especially when it's snowing outside.
Whenever you visit your pet monster, it can be very tricky to wake it up. Sometimes you like to let your pet monster sleep while you play by yourself.
Tell me about your pet monster. Does it always have a runny nose full of boogers or does it sleep with its tongue hanging out like a dog?
Your pet monster is covered in feathers! But it's not a bird, it doesn't look anything like a bird. It has a big wide grin full of little teeth for chomping on insects.

You found your pet monster while out walking in the trees, it had been holding onto a pinecone when the pinecone fell to the ground. It was lucky you were there to pick your poor pet monster up and brush off its feathers.
You thought it was a baby bird at first, but when you held it in your hand and saw that it had two arms and two legs as well as two wings, you just knew it had to be a monster!
Now it's your very own pet monster that you can visit outside as often as you like.
Your pet monster is wonderfully fluffy and cuddly. When it's asleep you can put your fluffy pet monster in your hand like a soft, tickly little ball.

When you first saw your pet monster, it was tucked up like a tiny fuzzy ball on the branch of a tree. When you poked it, your pet monster jumped to its feet thinking it was in danger! Luckily, you had snacks that you could share with the tiny monster so that it knew you were friendly.

Your pet monster reminds you of a turtle because whenever it gets cold or scared, it wraps its fluffy wings around its body and curls into a fuzzy little ball to hide and keep warm. It's never scared of you though because you're its best friend.
Your pet monster has big googly eyes. Its eyes are almost the same size as its head and make it look very strange.
Your pet monster wasn't always a wonderful acrobat, you had to show it how to swing on branches. It loved the game so much that it started swinging on branches even when you weren't there to watch.

Now your pet monster loves to practice being an acrobat all the time. Your pet monster can see very well with its big googly eyes which makes it easy for it to find bugs for its dinner, even tiny bugs flying through the air.

Your pet monster likes to share its dinner with you. If it finds a nice juicy caterpillar crawling on a tree branch, it will fly down to where you are sitting and give the caterpillar to you. Your pet monster never remembers that you don't like eating bugs!
Not all monsters have two eyes like people, some monsters have lots and other monsters have only one. Your pet monster doesn't have any eyes at all!
Your pet monster can hear very well and listens for the rustling of leaves on branches so it knows where to swing to while it's doing its amazing acrobat tricks.

It uses its nose to sniff out bugs for its dinner and its wings to keep balance as it sits in the trees to eat. Your pet monster has been teaching you how to do cartwheels and handstands which is a lot of fun.
You have been teaching your pet monster how to do somersaults and log rolls. Your pet monster thinks that rolling on the ground and getting dirty is very funny.
Your pet monster is always making grunting and growling noises when it moves around. It's not very sneaky because you can always hear it coming!
You first met your pet monster when it flew right in your window. One of your neighbours had heard a strange growling sound on his roof so he went upstairs with a big broom to see what the noise was.

Your pet monster got such a fright when your neighbour found it, that it flew off the roof and in your window. You were very surprised to see a monster fly into your bedroom, but it has been your pet ever since.
Sometimes you and your pet monster spend all day together talking in nothing but grunts and growls for fun.
Your pet monster likes to whistle a musical tune. It uses its funny round lips to blow out air and make music. Sometimes the whistling is beautiful but other times it just sounds terrible!
Sometimes you wish your pet monster could talk but the only noise it can make is whistling. You can always tell when it's happy or sad by the sound of its whistling.

Your pet monster is trying to teach you how to whistle but it's very difficult. You have to make your lips into a circle like you're blowing a kiss and then slowly blow out air. You practice together every time you go to the playground.
When you learn to whistle you and your pet monster will be able to make music together for other children to listen to at the playground!
Your pet monster makes terrible stinky farts! When you're reading or drawing, your pet monster likes to give you a fright by letting out very loud farts.
You've tried explaining to your pet monster that it has to go outside before it farts, but it never listens.
It's not so bad in the summer when you can leave the windows wide open. But during the winter when it's cold and all the windows need to stay shut, it's terribly stinky.
No one in your house likes coming into your room when your pet monster is visiting, pee-yew!
Maybe you should tell your pet monster to not eat so many bits of plastic and metal, it must make your pet monster's tummy very upset. That could be why it farts so much.

Your pet monster has long beautiful hair that you can brush. It will read a book and sit very still for you. It used to be a noisy grumpy monster before you found out that it likes having its hair brushed.
Now you know that any time your pet monster is being grumpy or noisy, the best way to calm it down is by getting out its special hair brush. It will settle down quickly once you start brushing.
Sometimes your pet monster gets so relaxed while you're brushing its long hair, it falls asleep!

While your pet monster is asleep on the floor, it's a good time to clean up any painting mess and tidy away toys and books. That way, when your pet monster wakes up, it can fly straight back to its bed on top of a building.
Your pet monster has long sharp claws but very soft feet. Whenever it runs around outside, it nearly always gets splinters and thorns stuck in its feet.
If it wasn't for its long claws, you would find your pet monster some shoes to wear, but the claws make wearing normal shoes impossible!
You and your pet monster have tried making shoes out of all sorts of things like mud and leaves and tree bark. But the shoes always fall off.
It's always a good idea to bring a plaster with you every time you visit your pet monster outside. That way you can help fix your pet monster's foot whenever it gets a splinter or thorn stuck in it.
You might need to take a tissue as well just in case your pet monster cries!
Your pet monster is very fast but also very clumsy. Sometimes when you're having a running race it will fall over and land on its hands and knees.
Once, when your pet monster was running very fast, it fell over and ended up doing a somersault! The somersault made your pet monster dizzy and upset.
So you dropped down onto your knees and did a somersault too! Your pet monster thought it was very funny and decided that doing somersaults was a new game.
Now whenever your pet monster falls over it does a somersault on purpose and starts a roly-poly game! It doesn't take long for both of you to get very dizzy doing somersaults together.
After a while, you need to lie on the ground and wait for everything to stop spinning!
One day when you were spending time with your pet monster outside, you both saw a person use a camera to take a photo.
Then you had to explain to your pet monster all about cameras and the photos they take. Now your pet monster loves having its photo taken.
It wants photos of all of its mud castles and of its underground tunnel where it sleeps. Sometimes when your pet monster is clean, you play dress up and take photos inside.
Your pet monster sometimes asks if it can take the photo but you have to say no because its big sharp claws might scratch the camera!
Because your pet monster likes to get dirty, when it's not building mud castles it likes to slide down big muddy hills.
It uses its sharp claws to dig away a smooth slide in the side of the hill before sliding down the slope on its bottom!

It's even more fun when your pet monster builds a mud castle at the bottom of the mud slide so it can crash into it. It makes a big muddy mess. Then your pet monster will rebuild its mud castle just to knock it over again on the next slide down.
You need to make sure you stand back when your pet monster crashes into its mud castle, otherwise you'll get covered in mud from head to toe!
Whenever your pet monster has finished its sliding fun, you need to remind it to find a puddle or a hose so that it can wash off all of the mud.
Inside its cave, your pet monster has built a little wooden stage. It uses this little stage to put on shows using its homemade masks and other toys.
Sometimes the shows are easy to understand, but most of the time you have no idea what is going on because your pet monster doesn't talk!
Your pet monster will stand by its little stage wriggling its masks and toys and you have to guess what the story is about.
Your favourite shows are the ones where your pet monster lets you be in the show too. You get to pick your favourite mask or toy and decide what the show is going to be about.
Sometimes you have people watching you, sometimes it's just you and your pet monster having fun together.
Your pet monster doesn't like being dirty and likes to have a bath every time it finishes making a new statue or mask. When it was your pet monster's birthday, you gave it the best present ever.

It was a water squirting toy that looked exactly like a rock! Now your pet monster can fill up its squirt toy before starts making a new statue, and then afterwards it can squirt the water onto its claws to clean them.
Your pet monster loves its new toy and even takes it into the bath!
Because the squirt toy is shaped like a rock, your pet monster can leave it on the ground and the other outdoor creatures will think it's just a normal rock and leave it alone.
Sometimes when your pet monster is being cheeky, it uses its toy to squirt water at you!
Your pet monster is not pretty when it sleeps because it always has a runny nose full of boogers! In fact, that was how you first found your pet monster.
You were walking outside and you thought it was just a big rock. But when you got closer the big rock blew a snot bubble out of its nose. Yuck!
When you asked the rock if it needed a tissue, it woke up and smiled at you. You've been best friends ever since.

You spend a lot of time trying to teach your pet monster how to wipe its nose with leaves because it doesn't have any tissues. But because it has big sharp claws, it finds wiping its nose very tricky!

Your pet monster has a long tongue which hangs out like a dog's whenever it's sleeping. Sometimes that's a problem because when your pet monster rolls onto its tummy while it's sleeping, its tongue falls right into the dirt!
Because your pet monster looks a bit like a dog when it sleeps, you sometimes imagine that it has its very own dog house with a water bowl even though you know that it lives inside a cave!
One time you tried to teach your pet monster how to play fetch. You found a good stick and threw it. Then your pet monster had to go and pick the stick up and bring it back.
Your pet monster didn't like the game very much at all. It would much rather spend its time sleeping. You will just have to think of a new game to play whenever you visit your pet monster.

books.title: Your Very Own Sea Creature
books.author: Meg Price
books.description: You are an underwater explorer! You have found a brand-new underwater sea creature.  With this interactive children's book, you get to choose your very own underwater sea creature. What does it look like? Where does it sleep? What secrets is it hiding? There are 16 different sea creatures to discover.

texts.text: You are an underwater explorer! While driving your fun blue submarine underwater, you discovered a brand-new kind of sea creature. A creature that has never been seen before.
It's lucky you have pictures of this amazing underwater sea creature because otherwise people might not believe that you saw it!
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it have tentacles or does it have a tail?
The amazing new sea creature you found has tentacles! Its tentacles have little suckers on the bottom for grabbing onto things.
The sea creature swims by wriggling its tentacles. It can swim very fast and you had to race along in your submarine to follow it as it swam all the way to its home.
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it live inside a shipwreck or inside an underwater cave?
The amazing new sea creature you found has a tail, but it's definitely not an ordinary fish!
You didn't spot the creature at first because you were looking through the window of your submarine at its amazing home. Then suddenly, you saw a tail poking out and waving in the water.
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it live in a big underwater castle, or does it live tucked inside a beautiful coloured coral reef?
The sea creature lives inside a shipwreck! It's a giant wooden ship that sits on the bottom of the sea.

It's like a maze that you had to carefully move your submarine through as you followed the sea creature. There were so many rooms to explore in the big shipwreck, but the creature knew exactly where it was taking you.
Tell me about the sea creature. Is it dark purple with big eyes, or is it a strange sparkly blue?
You followed the sea creature all the way to its home in an underwater cave.
The cave was big enough for you to drive your submarine right inside. It's lucky that your submarine has lights, otherwise it would have been too dark to see!
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it look like a round ball with tentacles all over, or does it have two long legs and four tentacle arms?
The sea creature lives in a giant underwater castle! It has towers and windows and a big front door.
There were visitors to the castle swimming everywhere, fish and dolphins and lots of other sea creatures. The castle is amazing, just like the creature that lives inside it.
Tell me about the sea creature. Is it just like a mermaid but with tails instead of hands, or is it a backwards mermaid with a fishy head and people legs?

The sea creature lives inside a beautiful coloured coral reef! You were busy looking at the amazing coral with its bright colours and strange shapes when you saw the tail of the sea creature poking out.
You drove your submarine closer thinking it was just a big fish, but it turned out to be something very different!
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it have two fishy tails, one at each end, or does it have a fishy tail and a long trunk like an elephant?
The sea creature you discovered is dark purple with big eyes. It has four long skinny tentacles that stretch out like a starfish.
Its big green eyes can see very well in the dark. You had quite an adventure following the strange looking creature through the rooms of the wooden shipwreck.
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it squirt clouds of ink when it's scared, or is it hiding pirate treasure?
The sea creature is a strange sparkly blue colour that twinkles underwater! It has a body like a jellyfish but instead of tentacles drooping downwards, the tentacles are on top of its head!
Because of its sparkly colour, it was very easy to follow the creature as it swam through the big wooden shipwreck.
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it like to play hide and seek, or does it build jigsaws for fun?
The sea creature looks like a round ball with tentacles all over! Some tentacles are long for grabbing things, others are short for shuffling along the sandy bottom of the sea.
It uses the suckers on its long tentacles to pick up and move shells and crabs out of the cave to keep its home tidy.
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it eat moss and mud, or can it squeeze through very tiny gaps between rocks?
The sea creature that you discovered has two long legs and four tentacle arms! Its legs have funny knobbly knees.
It wriggles all of its tentacle arms to swim, but it can also use its long legs to walk along the sandy bottom of the sea. Having two legs and four arms means the creature is very good at cartwheels.
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it sleep upside down like a bat, or does it like dancing to underwater musical beats?
The sea creature is just like a mermaid but with tails instead of hands! Just like a regular mermaid, it has the body and face of a person and long flowing hair.
But instead of only one beautiful tail, the creature has three! By using all three tails, it could swim so fast your submarine had trouble keeping up!
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it have other human friends, or can it make big underwater whirlpools?
The sea creature is a backwards mermaid with a fishy head and people legs!
You watched it swim with its legs tucked up to its scaly chest while its tail wriggled to move it through the water. You also saw it walking on its legs, but walking was much slower than swimming.
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it like to decorate its castle, or does it like to go exploring?

The sea creature has two fishy tails, one at each end! Because it has a tail at the top and the bottom of its body, the sea creature can change the direction of its swimming just by changing which tail it wriggles.
You watched it swim along in a crazy zig-zag pattern which was very tricky to follow in your submarine.
Tell me about the sea creature. Is it best friends with a giant eel, or does it make strange underwater barking noises?
The sea creature has a fishy tail and a long trunk like an elephant. Its body is big and blobby like a jellyfish. You were surprised to find out that the creature breathes air!
You watched it swim close to the surface and poke its trunk above the water to breathe, just like using a snorkel. Then it held its breath and swam back to the bottom of the sea.
Tell me about the sea creature. Does it like having swimming races, or does it have an amazing shell collection?
The sea creature squirts clouds of ink when it's scared, just like a squid! But the sea creature's ink isn't black like a squid's, it's strangely coloured.

You were following the creature through the shipwreck when your blue submarine bumped into a table and knocked it over. The table hit the floor with a bang and the creature got such a fright that it squirted a big cloud of dark ink with blobs of colour in it.

The cloud of coloured ink stuck to the window of your submarine and made it very difficult to see where you were going. Luckily, the creature was nice and used its tentacles to wipe the ink off the submarine's window so you could drive home safely.
The sea creature is hiding pirate treasure! You followed the purple creature though its shipwreck home until it swam into a room and quickly shut the door before you could go inside.

You had to drive your submarine out of the shipwreck and look inside all of the windows to find the right room. When you found the right window, you saw that the underwater sea creature had a big wooden chest full of pirate treasure!
The creature was protecting the treasure and was worried that you might steal it. You explained that you would never steal its treasure and that you would keep it a secret.
So the creature let you inside the treasure room so that you could look at all of the sparkling jewels and gold coins. What an amazing find!

The underwater sea creature likes to play hide and seek. You like hide and seek too, so you agreed to play. Because your submarine is big and the sea creature is a bright sparkly blue, you both found it very difficult to hide when it was your turn!

The creature would hide behind tables and benches inside the shipwreck. When it was your turn, you would hide your submarine inside big empty rooms and make your engine go quiet. Even though you were able to find each other very easily, it was still a lot of fun.

The creature had such a good time playing with you that it wants you to come back soon and play more hide and seek. Hopefully you can find the creature's shipwreck again the next time you take your submarine for a drive!

The sea creature builds jigsaws for fun! It must be very smart to have worked out how. You watched as it used coloured underwater clay to paint pictures on the wood before breaking the picture into small pieces to make a jigsaw.
It mixed all the pieces up with its tentacles and spread them out. Then it had to work out how to put the picture back together again.

The creature told you that making jigsaws is easy, all you need to do is colour a picture on some paper and rip it into pieces. You explained to the creature that at your house, you didn't use coloured clay because you have pencils and crayons instead.
When the creature asked if it could have some pencils, you had to explain that pencils don't work very well underwater!
The sea creature you found eats moss and mud for its dinner, yuck! After showing you inside its cave, the creature wanted to leave because it got hungry.
You followed while it crawled along the bottom of the sea on its short tentacles. It used its long tentacles to pick up dirty rocks and stones and put them in its mouth.

At first you thought it was eating the rocks, but then you saw the creature spit clean rocks back out. You realised that the creature was sucking the moss and mud right off the rocks! It was funny to watch so you helped the creature find more dirty rocks for its dinner.
When you got home after spending the day with the creature, you must have been very pleased to have regular food to eat at dinner time and not dirty rocks!

The sea creature can squeeze through very tiny gaps between rocks. You nearly lost the creature while you were following it along the bottom of the sea because it disappeared inside a big pile of rocks.
You had to drive your submarine to the other side of the rocks to look for the creature. A minute later, you saw a tentacle poke out through a gap in the rocks and wave at you.

Then you watched as the creature squeezed and squiggled, wriggled and jiggled its whole body through the tiny gap. It looked a bit like toothpaste squeezing out of a tube! Then the creature popped back to its normal shape and size. What an amazing trick!
The creature asked you to try squeezing through, but your submarine can't squish and squeeze, it would break!

The sea creature sleeps upside down like a bat! After spending all afternoon watching the sea creature do cartwheels on its long legs and tentacle arms, it was time for the creature to go back to its underwater cave to rest.

You followed it back to the cave and were surprised to see the creature turn upside down and hook its legs over the edge of a rock. It looked like it was hanging upside-down from monkey bars in a playground.
Then the creature closed its eyes and fell asleep with its head and tentacle arms hanging to the floor. What a funny way to sleep!
When you got home you tried to copy the creature by going upside-down and hooking your legs over the edge of your bed with your head on the floor. It was very uncomfortable!
The sea creature likes dancing to underwater musical beats! After it was finished doing cartwheels, it swam over to some rocks and coral.
The creature began to tap on the rocks and coral with its long tentacle arms, making a fun musical beat. Then it started to dance, hopping about on its legs in time to the beat.
The creature is a fantastic dancer and played the coral drums very well. You joined in the dancing by moving your blue submarine around in time to the beat.
You had to stop when all the bouncing made you dizzy, but the creature continued to play the coral drums and dance all afternoon!
When it was finally tired, it waved to you as it walked off along the sandy bottom of the sea on its way back to its cave to rest.

The sea creature likes to decorate its underwater castle. You watched while it collected shells and long pieces of green seaweed from the sandy bottom of the sea. It picked things up with its mouth and toes.
You followed the creature in and out of the castle many times until the creature had a big pile of things on the floor inside. Then it hung the seaweed up above the castle windows like curtains!

It used the shells as decorations on the walls. The sea creature liked to make each of the rooms in its castle beautiful. There were so many rooms in the castle that it would take the creature a very long time to decorate them all.
It told you that after it finished the whole castle, it would start all over again from the beginning!
The sea creature likes to go exploring! After it showed you through its amazing underwater castle, it wanted to show you something else.
You followed it in your blue submarine past coral reefs and giant boulders. It took you all the way to a giant hole in the bottom of the sandy sea floor.

It was very dark down in the hole and a bit scary. But the creature wasn't afraid, it loved exploring new places. You followed the creature as it swam slowly down inside the hole, tucking its legs up out of the way.
The walls of the giant hole were covered in beautiful sparkles which were so bright you didn't need to use your lights.

You were very pleased that you were brave enough to go exploring too, because it wasn't scary after all – it was beautiful! The creature promised that you could go exploring again when you next visit.
The sea creature has other human friends and it wanted you to meet them! With extra tails on its arms, it could swim very fast and you did you best to keep up as you both raced through the water.
The creature took you to a place where there were other people scuba diving! The scuba divers waved at you in your submarine and you waved back.

The creature was very happy to see you all getting along and invited everyone back to the castle. You knew that the scuba divers wouldn't be able to swim as fast as the creature so you told them to hang on tight to your submarine so you could pull them along.
After spending all afternoon in the castle with the creature, you gave the scuba divers another ride back to their boat on your way home. You hope that you see them again next time.
The sea creature can make big underwater whirlpools. Using its two extra tails, the creature can spin around and around, faster and faster, until it makes an underwater whirlpool!
The whirlpool sucks up sand from the bottom of the sea along with shells and rocks, bits of seaweed and even tiny fish. It all spins like a very fast merry-go-round.
You tried spinning your blue submarine around in circles to create your own whirlpool, but it wouldn't spin fast enough. Maybe your submarine needs three tails too!
When you got home, you started to notice whirlpools everywhere. There's one when you flush the toilet and another when you pull the plug out of the bath.
They're much smaller than the whirlpools the sea creature makes, but they're still fun to watch.
The sea creature is best friends with a giant eel. You didn't know that until you followed the strange two-tailed creature to a patch of coral not far from its home.
Before you reached the coral, a giant eel swam out to meet you. At first you were worried, but then you realised the creature and the giant eel were best friends and very happy to see each other.

When you drove your submarine closer, you saw that the eel was protecting something inside the coral. There were hundreds of two-tailed sea creature babies! The eel was looking after them while the creature was away.
The babies had never seen a submarine before and were very excited to meet you. You were surprised to find out that there isn't just one strange, two-tailed sea creature, there are hundreds!
The sea creature makes strange underwater barking noises! As you followed along behind it while it swam in a crazy zig-zag pattern, you heard a strange barking noise.
You realised the barking was coming from the two-tailed creature! It sounded a bit like a dog barking, but different because the noise was underwater.
You tried barking too, but the noise echoed inside your submarine and hurt your ears!

The creature swam closely to the sandy sea floor and barked so loudly that the sand puffed up in a cloud. Then you watched as the creature zig-zagged around eating the cloud of sand. It's a very interesting way to make dinner!

The sea creature likes to have swimming races! Because it needs to spend a lot of time near the surface so it can breathe, it has become friends with the seagulls who spend their time flying above the sea.
You watched from your submarine as the creature waved to a seagull with its trunk. The seagull flew closer until it was right above the creature. Then they set off on a race!

The creature swam through the water wriggling its tail fast and keeping its trunk above the water, while the seagull flew through the air. They were racing towards a big rock that had other seagulls sitting on it.
You and the other seagulls cheered as the racers got closer and closer to the finish line. Just before they both reached the rock, a big gust of wind slowed the seagull down and the sea creature won!
The sea creature has an amazing shell collection. As you drove your submarine around the beautiful coloured coral where it lived, you saw lots of shells in pretty patterns in the sand.
When the creature went back to the surface to take another breath of air through its trunk, you followed so that you could show the creature where the beach was.
The beach was covered in hundreds of shells. The creature was very excited and it swam close enough to the beach to reach the shells with its trunk.
It picked them up and tucked them under the flaps of its jellyfish body to carry them back to its wonderful underwater collection.
The next time you visit the creature, you're going to help it sort its shells from biggest to smallest. It might take all day!

books.title: Your Very Own Friendly Alien
books.author: Meg Price
books.description: You are an astronaut exploring outer space! On one of your stops on a far-away planet, you meet a friendly alien. With this interactive children's book, you get to choose your very own friendly alien. What does it look like? Where does it live? What fun thing do you do together? There are 16 different friendly aliens to discover.

texts.text: You are an astronaut exploring outer space! On one of your stops on a far-away planet, you meet a friendly alien.
The alien is very excited to show you around its planet which is very different from Earth, where you live.
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it have legs and walk around, or does it crawl around on its belly like a snail?
The friendly alien has legs. But it doesn't look very much like a person from Earth.

The alien can walk, run and jump, but it can't stand on its tippy toes because it doesn't have any toes to be tippy on! After the friendly alien looks inside your spaceship, you follow the alien to see its house.
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it live in a house that looks like a big bubble, or does it live on top of a very tall tower?
The friendly alien crawls around on its belly like a snail. But it's much bigger than a snail from Earth, the alien is as big as a person!
It wriggles and squiggles and shuffles and squirms. Look at it go! The friendly alien crawls on its belly so fast you need your spaceship to keep up!
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it live in place covered in heavy wet clouds, or does it live in a big flat sandy desert?
The friendly alien lives in a house like a big bubble. You see a whole alien town full of big bubble houses. When you touch the alien's house it wibbles and wobbles!
It's lucky there isn't any wind on this planet or the big bubble houses might float up and away!
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it have big sponges for hands, or is it made of bubbles too?
The friendly alien lives on top of a very tall tower. There are hundreds of steps to get to the top!
Looking high in the sky you can see the tippy top of the tower. It's the tallest building you've ever seen. The steps wind around the outside of the tower instead of inside, how strange!
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it have six legs, or four legs?
The friendly alien lives in a place covered in heavy wet clouds. The clouds sit down on the ground rather than high in the sky.
It's so foggy and gloopy, and wet and spooky inside the clouds, you can hardly see a thing! Your alien friend likes living inside the heavy wet clouds because heavy wet clouds are cosy and snuggly.
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it have two mouths, or does it have bumpy skin like a golf ball?
The friendly alien lives in a big flat sandy desert. The desert is very dry and very hot. That's because there isn't just one big happy sun shining down on the desert, there are two!

Planet Earth only has one sun, so for you, two suns feel like one sun too many. The suns even go to bed at different times, so one is always shining. There is no night time on this bright alien planet.
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it have telescope eyes, or does its body have lots of different colours?
The friendly alien has big sponges for hands! The sponges don't have any thumbs so grabbing and gripping things is very tricky.
The friendly alien eats balls covered in spikes. The spikes are so spikey they stick to the sponges! The alien chomps and chews and eats the balls, yummy scrummy, spikes and all.
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it like to clean, or does it like to play sports?
The friendly alien is made of bubbles too! It can even walk through the walls of its bubble house. It pushes and squeezes and walks right inside.
None of the bubble houses have any doors. You try pushing and squeezing and walking inside, but the bubble house just wibbles and wobbles and won't let you in!
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it grow alien vegetables, or does it play tricks, like hiding inside your spaceship?
The friendly alien has six legs! But it only uses two legs at a time. The alien walks and runs until its two legs get tired, then it tucks the tired legs away and uses two others!
The alien climbs hundreds of steps to the tippy top of its tall tower and changes legs many times. You huff and puff up the stairs wishing you had six legs too!
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it wear a backpack with a parachute inside or does it have a big red button at the top of its tower?
The friendly alien has four legs! There's a leg that goes up and a leg that goes down. There's a leg on its face and a leg on its bum!
The alien walks by tipping forward onto one leg at a time, rolling over and over like a bicycle wheel without a tire! If you walked like that, you would be very dizzy!
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it have a set of pretend legs for you to borrow, or does it want to show you how to eat space bugs?
The friendly alien has two mouths! One mouth has teeth for chomping and chewing while the other mouth has a big tongue for slurping and burping.
Because it has two mouths, it can eat dinner and drink water all at the same time!
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it want to read your book about different planets or can it turn invisible?

The friendly alien has bumpy skin like a golf ball! There are lots of little dents all over the alien, like tiny little bird baths. The alien looks like a giant scoop of ice-cream with all of the chocolate chips picked out!
When it rains inside the alien's cloudy home, all of its little bumps fill with water for the alien to drink.
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it make funny spots on the ground when it rolls around, or does it use long bendy straws to eat dinner?
The friendly alien has telescope eyes. It stretches its eyes all the way out to see things very far away. It uses a whole different set of eyes to see things very close up.
Its eyes are so amazing they can even smell smells! The alien stretches out its eyes to sniff and peep and snort and squint.
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it curl into a circle when it wants to move fast, or does it chase bouncy fluffy puffs across the desert?
The friendly alien's body has lots of different colours! It crawls on its belly very fast which makes the alien look like a squiggly wiggly, moving rainbow!
You find pictures of rainbows in a book on your spaceship and invite your alien friend to take a look. The alien is amazed and likes Earth rainbows very much.
Tell me about the friendly alien. Does it hide in a cave full of purple rocks or can it come apart like a jigsaw puzzle?
The friendly alien likes to clean. It has sticky tippy toes for walking up the side of the big bubble house. Then the alien uses its big wet tongue and soft spongy hands to scrub, scrub, scrub.

Its sticky tippy toes are so sticky the alien can even clean the big bubble house inside and upside down! All of the aliens in the bubble town like cleaning so much that they clean their big bubble houses every single day.
When your new friend finishes cleaning its home, it walks over to your spaceship and keeps right on cleaning. It scrubs your spaceship inside, outside, topside and underneath.
Its big wet tongue slurps and slops and its spongy hands scrub and mop. When the alien is finished, your spaceship is wonderfully, sparkling clean!

The friendly alien likes to play sports. Its favourite game is a mix of racing and ball kicking. Two aliens line up to play and when a loud whistle blows , they start running. They kick a ball back and forth and forth and back while running as fast as they can.
They race past houses and trees and family and friends. You watch the two aliens zoom past while you cheer and clap your hands. The two aliens kick and run and run and kick, faster and faster.
The alien who reaches the finish line first is the winner. Then it's your turn to try. You run as fast as you can in your spacesuit, but your big space boots are very heavy.
When you kick the ball, your heavy boots hit it so hard it flies right over the bubble houses and is lost out in space! Oh no! It's all okay though, you can find the ball using your spaceship.
The friendly alien grows alien vegetables. It has a special big bubble house just for growing things. Some vegetables grow out of the ground and some hang from the ceiling.

There are vegetables that look like jellyfish and vegetables that look like trumpets. You can't go inside the big garden bubble because there's no doors for you to use. But you can see through the walls all the amazing things growing like a strange bubble jungle.
The friendly alien picks a tasty blue bubble-squirt for you to try. It pokes the bubble-squirt at the helmet of your spacesuit to put it in your mouth.
But your helmet is just like a bubble house with no door! You can't eat with your helmet on, so you put the blue bubble-squirt in your pocket to taste when you get home.

The friendly alien likes to play tricks, like hiding inside your spaceship! It sneakily sneaks on board when you're not looking. When you're ready to go home you feel sad because you can't find your new alien friend to say goodbye!

It's time to leave so you sit in the captain's chair of your spaceship and boop the buttons and lift the levers to make the spaceship take off. But you don't know the alien is hiding on board as you start heading home!
You are almost halfway to Earth when the alien jumps out to surprise you, ta-da! You get such a fright! What a naughty alien.
You have to turn your spaceship around and fly all the way back to the alien's planet to take your silly friend home. You say your goodbyes and promise to visit again soon.

The friendly alien wears a backpack with a parachute inside. It uses the parachute to get down from its tower. When the alien is ready, it stands at the edge of the tippy top of its tall tower and jumps!
Then a big pretty parachute puffs up out of the backpack. The alien floats slowly and gently all the way to the ground. It pushes the parachute back inside the backpack, ready for next time.

When the weather is windy the ride down can get loopy. Sometimes the wind swoops up the alien and its parachute and swishes it far away! Then the alien has to use its six short legs to walk all the way home.
After a long walk, the alien has to rest before it can climb the hundreds of stairs up to the tippy top of the tall tower. It's all very tiring!

The friendly alien has a big red button at the top of its tower. The button is round and even bigger than you! Your alien friend jumps onto the button and just like that, the hundreds of stairs are no longer there! Instead there is a giant slide!

The slide twists and turns around the tower. It goes all the way from the tippy top of the tower to the dusty desert ground. The alien cheers and sits on the slide to woosh and swoosh all the way down.

Sliding down slides is more fun than walking down stairs, so you sit on the slide too. The slide is long and you speed along faster and faster. The slide is loopy and you swoop around and around the tower.
When the bottom is just ahead, you land on the ground with two feet and a very dizzy head!
The friendly alien has a set of pretend legs for you to borrow. They're curly and bouncy and stick to your spacesuit. The legs are yellow just like your space boots!

To walk like your new friend, you need a leg that goes up and a leg that goes down, a leg on your belly and a leg on your bum! The alien legs are springy, just like a spring. You jump and you bounce and you roll up the stairs.

You tip upside down and downside up. Every time you tip forward to use the leg on your head, you worry that you'll wobble and tip off the stairs instead! But your friend is there to help and to keep you safe.

You roll higher and higher getting dizzier and dizzier. When you reach the tippy top of the tall tower you have to sit down for a minute for your head to stop spinning. But there's a leg on your bum which keeps right on springing!
The friendly alien wants to show you how to eat space bugs! The alien is like a vacuum cleaner with four hoses. Its legs are also trunks made for slurping up bugs!

It walks up the stairs from one leg to the next while it sucks and it slurps and gobbles its lunch. There are so many stairs and so many bugs that by the time the alien reaches the tippy top of the tall tower, it is full enough to burst!

Sometimes the stairs are covered in dust. When your alien friend walks and slurps dust up its trunks, it sneezes AH CHOO! It doesn't just sneeze out of one trunk leg, it sneezes out of all four at the same time. AH CHOO, CHOO, CHOO, CHOO, it sounds like a train.
A train with four trunks. Trunks that are legs. Legs for walking up hundreds of stairs. Legs that are trunks that also eat bugs!

The friendly alien wants to read your book about different planets. You spend all day telling the alien about planet Earth. Your new friend wants to see a picture of Earth, so you find your big book of planets.

You flip through the pages of planets until you find Earth. It's a beautiful blue and glorious green colour. You flip through the pages of planets until you find the alien's home. It's a pretty purple and rocking orange colour. The planets are very different.

Your alien friend wants to come home with you to see planet Earth, but the spaceship only has one seat. Instead, you leave your big book of planets with the alien so it can see the pictures and practice reading.
You promise to visit again soon with more big books full of interesting things.
The friendly alien can turn invisible! You're walking through the heavy wet clouds that cover the ground, but the alien disappears when you turn around.
The invisible alien watches as you look everywhere. It giggles and jiggles because you're so near! The cheeky alien decides to eat lunch while you look.

You keep walking further and further away until you hear noises. There's lots of crunching and slurping and biting and burping! You follow the yucky sounds until you bump into your invisible friend, but you still can't see them!

Then your friend giggles and jiggles loudly and you know that it's there! The alien changes so you can see it again. Your alien friend played a trick on you! At first you're a bit grumpy, but the alien laughs and then you think it's funny.
The friendly alien makes funny spots on the ground when it rolls around. The spots are like footprints, but the alien doesn't have feet! If the footprints aren't from a foot, what do you call them?
The alien is round with no arms, legs or feet. So the prints must be body prints, left on the ground as the alien rolls around. There are little bumps in the dirt everywhere the alien goes.

You try to play hide and seek, but the alien is too easy to find. You just follow the spots on the ground. You sneak along and creep along, following the spots. Your big space boots squish the spots as you step on them.

When you reach a big rock, you know the alien is hiding behind it. You take one last step around the rock and find your friend. The alien is surprised you found it so fast. It forgets about the spots it makes on the ground whenever it rolls around.
The friendly alien uses long bendy straws to eat dinner. The alien says that bendy straws are more fun than straight straws. It has two different bendy straws, one for drinking and one for eating.

Whenever it rains, water sits in the bumps on its skin. The alien uses a bendy straw to drink the water off its own back! When the alien is hungry it eats dirt. It sucks the dirt right off the ground using the other bendy straw.
The alien can eat and drink at the same time! The water gurgles through one straw while dirt wriggles though the other straw.

The alien asks if you would like to share its dinner, but you don't want to drink water off its back or eat dirt off the ground! You say “No, thank you.” The alien doesn't mind. It gurgles and slurps and sucks on its bendy straws until it's all full.

The friendly alien curls into a circle when it wants to move fast. It looks like a wheel as it rolls along as fast as a race car! The alien likes to chase space puppies all over the desert, just for fun.

It stretches out its telescope eyes to squint and sniff and snort and look for space puppies running around the desert. When it sees or sniffs one, the alien curls into a big ball and rolls after the space puppy.

The alien zigs and zags and zooms and vrooms all over the dusty desert. It keeps one eye pointed at the space puppy so it knows where to roll. The alien doesn't get dizzy as its body spins around and around in the sand.

You try to follow the alien by doing rolly pollys. You tuck your helmet to your belly and roll over and over again. But you can't roll as fast as the alien and the dusty desert makes your spacesuit all dirty! Instead you wait for the alien to catch a space puppy for you to pat.

The friendly alien chases bouncy fluffy puffs across the desert! The fluffy puffs bounce out of holes in the ground. The alien uses its telescope eyes to see and sniff how many fluffy puffs it can spy.
Nobody knows what makes fluffy puffs bounce. They bounce up in the air where they float and they flutter. The alien runs out to catch them to have them as supper!
You eat one of the fluffy puffs just to try it. You decide that they're tasty and you like it. The puffs are all fluffy like cotton candy. Or maybe the fluff is all puffy like a marshmallow.

The strange alien food is yummy either way. Maybe you could grow some back on Earth? It's impossible to say. The alien gives you some fluffy puffs to take on your spaceship. When you get home, you'll dig holes where the fluffy puffs can stay.

The friendly alien hides in a cave full of purple rocks. The cave is cold, so the alien snuggles and squishes its body together. The alien's ears stick up because they don't fold down. It makes it much easier to hear what's around.

. It's always hot out in the desert but sometimes the alien likes being cold. So it hides inside the big chilly cave away from the two suns. The alien looks for a smooth patch of ground between the purple rocks, then folds itself down like a pile of blocks.
When it's all squished and squeezed into half its normal size, the alien reminds you of the coloured stacking blocks you like to play with. All of the colours fit inside each other.
When the alien is ready to stretch back out to full size, it unfolds one colour at a time, pop, pop, pop!

The friendly alien can come apart like a jigsaw puzzle! The alien has pieces in all different colours. Some pieces have spots and others have scales. Some pieces are smooth and other pieces are hairy!

The alien leaves its pieces lying around in the desert. Sometimes the alien even forgets where it leaves the pieces and has to search for them. One of the puzzle pieces is fluffy and the same colour as the dusty desert. When that piece is lost, it's very tricky to find!
Your new friend needs your help to find all of its pieces. You walk back and forth and forth and back, all over the dusty desert looking for the pieces of puzzle the alien left lying around.

The alien has ten puzzle pieces, so you count the pieces as you find them. The first nine are easy but the last one is tricky. Finally, you find the final fluffy piece. The alien puts its pieces back together and is very pleased.
